title: How to Remove Hair Dye from a Wall

steps.title: Test the alcohol on a small area.
steps.content: Test the alcohol on a small area. Wet a cotton ball with alcohol and rub it on an inconspicuous spot on the wall, first. Check for stains, discoloration, or residue. If the alcohol produces any unwanted affects, then try a different method. [2] X Research source You should always test products and solutions on small, hidden areas first before using them on larger surfaces to avoid unwanted effects.

steps.title: Dampen a clean, white cloth with the alcohol.
steps.content: Dampen a clean, white cloth with the alcohol. Hold the cloth with your finger on top of the bottleâ€™s opening. In a quick motion, turn the bottle upside down then right side up again to dampen the cloth. Then gently rub the cloth over the stain in a circular motion. Once the stain begins to transfer to the cloth, use a different area of the cloth to finish cleaning the stain. [3] X Research source Alternatively, you can use nail polish remover if the rubbing alcohol does not work. Just remember to wipe the area clean with water before applying the nail polish remover onto the stain. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe the area clean with a towel.
steps.content: Wipe the area clean with a towel. Use a wet towel to remove the rubbing alcohol from the wall once the stain is gone. Then use a clean, dry towel to dry the area.

steps.title: Wet the eraser under running water.
steps.content: Wet the eraser under running water. Squeeze the eraser to remove any excess water before applying it to the hair dye stain. [5] X Research source Remember to test the eraser on a small, hidden area first before applying it to larger surfaces.

steps.title: Scrub the area in a circular motion.
steps.content: Scrub the area in a circular motion. Make sure to scrub the stain gently. However, if the stain is not coming out, you may scrub harder. If the eraser becomes dry, re-wet it and keep scrubbing until the hair dye stain is removed. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Use a clean towel to dry the spot.
steps.content: Use a clean towel to dry the spot. Wipe a clean, dry towel over the area. If you want, you can clean the area first with a wet towel before drying it.

steps.title: Sand the wall.
steps.content: Sand the wall. Use fine-grit, 120 sandpaper to sand the area. Working from the top to the bottom, sand the area in a horizontal motion, i.e., parallel to the ceiling and baseboard. Use a sanding pole to sand large areas like an entire wall. To avoid a patchy appearance, you may want to sand, prime, and repaint the whole wall.

steps.title: Wipe the surface with a clean, wet cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the surface with a clean, wet cloth. The cloth will remove any debris leftover from the sanding. Wipe until all the debris is removed. Then dry the surface with a clean towel, or let it air dry. [7] X Research source You can use a gentle cleanser or plain water to clean your wall.

steps.title: Apply a coat of primer.
steps.content: Apply a coat of primer. Apply the coat with a separate primer brush in a straight up and down motion. You may need to let the primer set for 24 hours, however, it depends on the type of primer you bought. Therefore, make sure to follow the instructions on the bottle.

steps.title: Re-sand the primer.
steps.content: Re-sand the primer. Do this once the primer is dry. Sand in a horizontal motion until the surface is smooth. Then wipe down the surface again to remove any debris. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Repaint the wall with at least two coats of paint.
steps.content: Repaint the wall with at least two coats of paint. Dip a clean or new paintbrush into your bucket of paint until one-third of the brush is covered in paint. Tap the brush against the side of the can to remove excess paint. Paint the area in a straight up and down motion. Let the first coat dry completely before applying a second or third coat. When painting the wall, try to paint in full daylight so you can get an even finish. You can sand in between paint jobs to get a professional look. Apply as many coats as you need until the color you want is achieved.
